metadata.title: OpenShift 4 Implementation Guide for ISA/IEC 62443-4-2 SL-4

components.title: Red Hat OpenShift Container Platform 4
components.description: A comprehensive enterprise Kubernetes platform for building and running cloud-native applications, configured to meet ISA/IEC 62443-4-2 SL-4 based on the OpenShift 4 Implementation Guide.

control-implementations.description: Implementation of ISA/IEC 62443-4-2 controls for an SL-4 baseline, based on the OpenShift 4 Implementation Guide.

implemented-requirements.description:
**Method:** Procedural

All human user authentication must be handled by integrating OpenShift with a central, enterprise Identity Provider (IdP) that supports OpenID Connect (OIDC). Direct password-based login (e.g., using htpasswd) must be disabled. The customer is responsible for configuring the oauth.config.openshift.io custom resource to point to their IdP.

**Method:** Procedural

This control is satisfied by the central IdP, which must be configured to enforce unique user identifiers for all personnel. During the OIDC integration (detailed in CR-1.1), the spec.identityProviders.openID.claims section of the OAuth configuration is used to map a unique, immutable claim from the IdP (like email or sub) to the OpenShift User object's preferredUsername. This ensures every user in the cluster has a persistent, unique identity tied to the IdP.

**Method:** Procedural

Multi-factor authentication is enforced entirely by the central IdP. OpenShift delegates the authentication process; it does not implement an MFA mechanism itself. If the IdP's policy requires MFA for a user, the user must complete that challenge before the IdP issues an authentication token. OpenShift then accepts this token, trusting that the IdP has successfully verified the user's identity according to its policies.

**Method:** Built-in

This is inherently met. Every pod within the cluster runs with a unique, cryptographically verifiable identity called a ServiceAccount. Communication between core OpenShift components (e.g., kubelet to API server) is mutually authenticated using a built-in Public Key Infrastructure (PKI).

**Method:** Procedural

The customer must have a documented Identity and Access Management (IAM) policy for managing the full lifecycle (creation, modification, deletion) of user accounts within their central IdP. OpenShift can be configured to synchronize group membership from the IdP, ensuring that a user's permissions are automatically revoked or updated when their status changes in the IdP.

links.text: Syncing groups with an OIDC provider

implemented-requirements.description:
**Method:** Procedural

All human user authenticators (passwords, tokens, etc.) are managed by the central IdP. For non-human ServiceAccount tokens used for automation, a procedure must exist to issue tokens with least-privilege roles and a short, fixed lifetime. Bound service account tokens, which are automatically mounted into pods, are short-lived, automatically rotated JWTs.

**Method:** Infrastructure

The physical server nodes running OpenShift must be equipped with a TPM 2.0 module. When installing the cluster, you must enable disk encryption for nodes, which can then seal the LUKS disk encryption key into the TPM.

**Method:** Procedural

All password policies (length, complexity, history, lifetime) are configured and enforced by the customer's central IdP, not by OpenShift.

**Method:** Procedural

The customer must replace the default ingress and API server TLS certificates with certificates issued from their own trusted Certificate Authority (CA).

links.text: Setting a custom default certificate for the Ingress Controller

implemented-requirements.description:
**Method:** Infrastructure

For SL-4, the customer's CA should be a hardware-based CA (using an HSM). SSH private keys for node administration should be stored on hardware security tokens (e.g., YubiKey) and accessed via a bastion host.

**Method:** Shared (Inherited & Customer-Specific / Compensating)

This control is a shared responsibility. The primary method is for the customer to use a hardened, enterprise-grade Identity Provider (IdP) designed to protect against timing-based user enumeration attacks. The visual feedback from the OpenShift login interface is inherently generic and non-enumerating. If using the internal htpasswd provider, compensating controls (rich audit logging, SIEM-based brute-force mitigation, and network-level isolation) must be implemented.

**Method:** Procedural

This is enforced by the customer's central IdP, which must have policies to detect and respond to brute-force attacks, including temporary account lockout.

**Method:** Automated

A system use notification banner must be displayed at the web console login. This is configured by applying a ConsoleNotification custom resource.

**Method:** Procedural & Infrastructure

This is satisfied by using LUKS full-disk encryption on the host OS, which must be configured during installation and have its key sealed in a hardware TPM 2.0 module. (See CR-1.5 RE(1)).

**Method:** Automated

This is a core feature of OpenShift, managed by Role-Based Access Control (RBAC). The customer must implement a detailed RBAC model using Role, ClusterRole, and RoleBinding objects to enforce a principle of least privilege.

links.text: Using RBAC to define and apply permissions

implemented-requirements.description:
**Method:** Procedural

The customer must have a documented "break-glass" procedure for emergency access to the kubeadmin account. The kubeadmin password should be stored securely (e.g., in a vault) and access should require supervisory approval. All actions performed by kubeadmin are captured in the cluster audit logs with the username kube:admin.

**Method:** Shared (Procedural & Automated)

This control is a shared responsibility satisfied by combining a procedural GitOps workflow with a technically enforced, role-based approval mechanism. A baseline GitOps peer review (e.g., pull request) establishes general two-person control. This is enhanced for high-risk components using a CODEOWNERS file in Git for role-specific approvals. For the most critical actions, a manual-approval gate must be implemented in the CI/CD pipeline (e.g., Tekton) to provide a final, auditable runtime approval.

**Method:** Infrastructure & Host OS (Layered Control)

A defense-in-depth strategy is required. The primary control is disabling all wireless networking hardware in the UEFI/BIOS of all server nodes. A secondary control, implemented via MachineConfig, blacklists common wireless kernel modules (e.g., iwlwifi, brcmsmac) to prevent the use of unauthorized USB wireless devices. A tertiary procedural control must include periodic physical inspection.

*e.*Method:** Automated

In OpenShift, "mobile code" is the container imag This is controlled by requiring that all images are signed and come from a trusted registry. The cluster's admission controller must be configured to only allow verified images. An ImageContentSourcePolicy can be used to force all image pulls to resolve to a trusted internal registry, and an admission controller (like Red Hat Advanced Cluster Security) must verify image signatures.

**Method:** Procedural

Session timeouts must be configured in the OpenShift OAuth server settings (tokenConfig.accessTokenInactivityTimeout) and in the customer's central IdP.

**Method:** Procedural

This is enforced by the customer's central IdP.

**Method:** Procedural

The customer must deploy the Cluster Logging and Cluster Log Forwarding operators and configure them to send all audit and container logs to a central, hardened SIEM.

links.text: Forwarding cluster logs to third-party systems

implemented-requirements.description:
**Method:** Automated & Procedural

The PTP Operator must be deployed and configured to synchronize all cluster nodes with a trusted, customer-provided NTP server. For SL-4, this should be a cryptographically secured time source. This is complemented by a MachineConfig that sets the node's chrony service to point to the trusted NTP source.

**Method:** Built-in

This is inherently met by the detailed API server audit logs, which link every action to a unique user or service account identity and a timestamp. Forwarding these logs to a WORM-compliant SIEM ensures their integrity.

**Method:** Automated & Built-in

All internal component communication is mutually authenticated via a built-in PKI over TLS. For external communication, the API Server's TLS Security Profile must be set to 'Modern' or 'Intermediate' (via APIServer cluster patch) to enforce strong ciphers.

**Method:** Built-in & Procedural

OpenShift provides defense-in-depth against malware through SELinux, immutable container images, and read-only file systems. The customer must procedurally implement container image vulnerability scanning in their CI/CD pipeline, typically using a tool like Red Hat Advanced Cluster Security (ACS) or Red Hat Quay.

links.text: About Red Hat Advanced Cluster Security for Kubernetes

implemented-requirements.description:
**Method:** Automated & Procedural

The customer must deploy the Compliance Operator, which continuously scans and verifies the cluster's configuration against a defined security profile (e.g., CIS Benchmark) by creating a ScanSettingBinding.

**Method:** Built-in & Automated

The integrity of the host OS (RHCOS) is guaranteed by the immutable rpm-ostree file system. The customer must deploy the File Integrity Operator to monitor for changes to critical files and report violations by deploying a FileIntegrity resource.

**Method:** Built-in

These are inherently met by the design of OpenShift and its use of modern web standards and protocols like TLS and OIDC.

**Method:** Procedural

The customer must ensure that their central SIEM, which receives all forwarded logs (see CR-2.8), uses WORM-compliant or immutable storage to prevent tampering of audit records.

**Method:** Infrastructure

The server hardware must have chassis intrusion detection enabled in the BIOS/UEFI, and the data center must have physical access controls (e.g., locked cages, video surveillance).

**Method:** Infrastructure

UEFI Secure Boot must be enabled in the server's hardware settings for all cluster nodes to ensure only signed bootloaders and kernels can be executed. This is a prerequisite for the RHCOS installation.

**Method:** Procedural & Automated

Data in transit is protected by TLS. Data at rest for the host OS is protected by LUKS encryption (See CR-1.5 RE(1)). For etcd, the customer must enable etcd encryption for application secrets by patching the apiserver config to enable aescbc and running a script to rewrite all secrets.

**Method:** Procedural & Built-in

The Linux kernel provides built-in clearing of volatile memory upon process termination. The customer must have a procedural media sanitization policy (e.g., following NIST SP 800-88) for decommissioning nodes and storage devices.

**Method:** Built-in

OpenShift uses FIPS 140-2 validated cryptographic modules when the host OS (RHCOS) is installed in FIPS mode. This must be enabled during the initial cluster installation and cannot be changed later.

**Method:** Automated

The customer must implement a default-deny network posture using NetworkPolicy objects, which are applied via a GitOps workflow to enforce micro-segmentation between pods. This includes applying a 'default-deny-all' policy to a namespace and then explicitly allowing required traffic (e.g., from the OpenShift router).

**Method:** Procedural

This is satisfied by configuring log forwarding to a central SIEM (see CR-2.8). The security operations team must have real-time access to these logs and have pre-configured alerts and dashboards to detect and respond to security events.

**Method:** Automated

DoS protection is provided by applying LimitRange and ResourceQuota objects to namespaces and by hardening the host OS kernel's TCP/IP stack.

**Method:** Automated

All application pods must have resource requests and limits defined in their manifests. The customer must also apply resource quotas to critical OpenShift namespaces (e.g., openshift-* ).

**Method:** Procedural

The customer must deploy and configure the OpenShift API for Data Protection (OADP) operator to perform regular, automated backups of cluster resources and persistent volumes to a secure, external location (e.g., S3-compatible object storage).

links.text: About OADP for cluster backup and restore

implemented-requirements.description:
**Method:** Procedural

The customer must have a documented and annually tested disaster recovery plan that uses OADP backups and the GitOps repository to reconstitute the cluster in a separate physical location.

**Method:** Infrastructure

The data center must provide UPS for all server racks and backup generator power capable of sustaining the full load for a defined period (e.g., 72 hours).

**Method:** Built-in

The GitOps repository serves as the single source of truth for all configuration settings, providing a machine-readable, version-controlled, and auditable record of the cluster's intended state.

**Method:** Built-in

The host OS (RHCOS) is minimal by design. The customer should review and disable any default cluster operators that are not required for their specific workload to reduce the attack surface.

**Method:** Built-in & Procedural

The oc get clusterversion command provides a built-in software inventory of core OpenShift components. The customer must use a centralized asset management tool for a full system inventory, including hardware, networking devices, and external services.
